item.title: F.D.A. OKs Moderna Vaccine, Adding Millions of Doses to U.S. Supply
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence got the shot today. “I didn’t feel a thing,” he said. California reported 3 percent availability of I.C.U. beds. Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Homeland Security’s Latest Target: Vaccine Scams
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse preparing doses of the Pfizer vaccine at Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia. Fraudsters and organized crime networks are looking to take advantage of the high demand for the coronavirus vaccine.
item.description: A division of the Immigrations and Customs Enforcement agency, working with the Justice Department, is hunting down websites offering fraudulent deals to buy coronavirus vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: United Helps to Contact Passengers After Possible Covid-19-Related Death on Flight
item.media:description: A United Airlines plane takes off from Los Angeles International Airport.
item.description: The flight, United 591 from Orlando to Los Angeles, was diverted to New Orleans on Monday after a passenger had a medical emergency on board.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: Trump Claims Credit for Vaccines. Some of His Backers Don’t Want to Take Them.
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pharmacist preparing a dose of the Pfizer vaccine for the coronavirus on Wednesday. The “anti-vaxxer movement” is not new, and it typically cuts across political parties. But partisanship plays a major role in how people view the coronavirus vaccine.
item.description: A deep distrust of the government is fueling vaccine hesitancy among Republicans, who are more likely than Democrats to resist being inoculated against Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg

item.title: Can a Televised Vaccination Undo Months of Skepticism?
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence receiving a Covid-19 vaccine at the White House on Friday.
item.description: A few minutes of morning television distilled the various ways that President Trump and his political allies have undermined confidence in the science about the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters

item.title: Congress Clears Two-Day Spending Extension to Finalize Stimulus Deal
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite a last-minute hurdle — and continuing haggling over the details of unemployment benefits, small-business funds and disaster aid for state and local governments — congressional leaders and aides insisted they were closer than they had ever been.
item.description: The short time frame signaled optimism that Congress could come to agreement on the $900 billion economic recovery plan, but a last-minute dispute over the Fed’s lending powers emerged as a stubborn final sticking point.
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane

item.title: What Is 13-3? Why a Debate Over the Fed Is Holding Up Stimulus Talks
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Republicans are trying to make sure that emergency programs backed by the Federal Reserve cannot be restarted after they expire on December 31.
item.description: The Fed’s emergency lending authorities are a key part of its job. Republicans want to curb them. Democrats are pushing back.
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Trump’s Future: Tons of Cash and Plenty of Options for Spending It
item.media:description: President Trump during a rally in Valdosta, Ga., this month.
item.description: When President Trump departs the White House, he will have a huge pile of cash to fuel his future ambitions. He can hold rallies, hire staff and even lay groundwork for a potential 2024 run.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

item.title: Lara Trump served on the board of a company through which the Trump political operation spent more than $700 million.
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lara Trump at a news conference with President Trump’s lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani in Philadelphia last month.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

item.title: N.Y.C. to Change Many Selective Schools to Address Segregation
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio is making changes that will affect how about 400 of the New York City’s 1,800 schools admit students.
item.description: The pandemic prompted the mayor’s most significant action yet on integration: a major shift in how hundreds of schools admit students.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro

item.title: N.Y.P.D. Badly Mishandled George Floyd Protests, Watchdog Says
item.media:credit: Amr Alfiky for The New York Times
item.media:description: A report found that the Police Department was poorly prepared to handle the protests that followed the police killing of George Floyd.
item.description: “I look back with remorse,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said after a city oversight agency found the department’s tactics “produced excessive enforcement.”
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: A Riveting ISIS Story, Told in a Times Podcast, Falls Apart
item.description: A Canadian’s gruesome account as an Islamic State executioner in Syria, which was the subject of the “Caliphate” podcast by The New York Times, was fabricated, officials say. A Times review found no corroboration of his claim to have committed atrocities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Ian Austen, Graham Bowley and Malachy Browne

item.title: New York Times Says ‘Caliphate’ Podcast Fell Short of Standards
item.media:description: It hit the top of the Apple podcast charts in 2018 and won major journalism awards, but now The Times says “Caliphate” contained flawed reporting.
item.description: The Times cited an institutional failure and determined the “Caliphate” team gave too much credence to the claims of a supposed former terrorist.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy, Katie Robertson and Tiffany Hsu

item.title: Is There Such a Thing as a Humane Eviction?
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sheriff places a notice to quit, the first stage in an eviction process, in the door of an apartment in Springfield, Mass.
item.description: As a bulge of evictions looms, a Massachusetts sheriff is searching for ways to soften the blow.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

item.title: Government Shutdown, Moderna, Holiday Lights: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr.

item.title: 10 Powerful ‘Daily’ Episodes From 2020
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters marched in New York in June as anger spread across the country.
item.description: In a year defined by a pandemic, protests and politics, “The Daily” sought out personal stories. Here’s a holiday playlist of the episodes that Michael Barbaro and our team can’t forget.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: A Holiday Lesson About Desire
item.description: This holiday season, it’s OK to want more.

item.title: ‘The 46th’: Will Georgia’s Races Change the Senate?
item.description: Jamelle Bouie joins Michelle and Ross to predict the results of the runoff elections.

item.title: Fire Robert Wilkie
item.description: The Department of Veterans Affairs secretary no longer has the trust of those who served.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: How the Coronavirus Changed Death
item.description: How the pandemic is changing our understanding of mortality.
item.dc:creator: BJ Miller

item.title: Facebook’s Tone-Deaf Attack on Apple
item.description: The company declared in newspaper ads that it was “standing up to Apple.” It’s a desperate ploy that’s unlikely to work.
item.dc:creator: Kara Swisher

item.title: You’re Choosing a Gift. Here’s What Not to Do.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lucy Jones; Photograph by TokenPhoto, via Getty Images
item.description: Many of our natural impulses turn out to be wrong. Psychological research can help us choose wisely.
item.dc:creator: Daniel T. Willingham

item.title: Lewis and Clark's Long, Dark Winter. And Ours.
item.media:credit: Carleton E. Watkins, via The Metropolitan Museum of Art
item.media:description: “Cape Horn near Celilo,” photographed by Carleton Watkins in 1867 near the Columbia River in Oregon.
item.description: Lessons from Lewis and Clark on living through the darkest days and longest nights.
item.category: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
item.dc:creator: Timothy Egan

item.title: Why Lisa Montgomery Shouldn't Be Executed
item.description: The execution of Lisa Montgomery would be an injustice on top of an injustice.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Snyder

item.title: When Doctors Go Off Script on Covid
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Scott W. Atlas had caught President Trump’s eye with his frequent appearances on Fox News over the summer.
item.description: Readers say there should be consequences for dismissing the science. Another says medical advances depend on unconventional ideas.

item.title: The World Is Full of Challenges. Here’s How Biden Can Meet Them.
item.description: The incoming administration needs to update American policy to meet the challenges of the 21st century.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: Robert M. Gates

item.title: How to Reform the Presidency After the Wreckage of Trump
item.description: Our post-Watergate laws and practices for the presidency need revamping.
item.dc:creator: Bob Bauer and Jack Goldsmith

item.title: The W.T.O. Is Having a Midlife Crisis
item.media:credit: Illustration by Michael Houtz; photograph by Getty Images
item.description: Fixing the global trading system means first coming to grips with why it is broken.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

item.title: This Solstice, Solace for the Darkness
item.media:description: An Indigenous Mapuche girl watched the solar eclipse from Chile on Monday.
item.description: A rare conjunction of planets serves as a reminder that there is more to the universe than just ourselves.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: How Much Dyker Heights Christmas Light Displays Cost
item.description: Nine snowflakes, eight penguins, five angels and three life-size Nutcrackers. “I spend several thousand dollars — at the least — each year.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg

item.title: Lost and Found: A Missing Camus Biography and a Christmas Miracle
item.description: Geoff Dyer remembers the book that came back.
item.dc:creator: Geoff Dyer

item.title: Pandemic Delays 9/11 Trial Past 20th Anniversary of Attacks
item.media:description: A memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks this year in New York. The start of the trial of the accused mastermind Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four accused co-conspirators will now start on Nov. 7, 2021, at the earliest.
item.description: The coronavirus crisis has compounded other problems in the troubled case at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Calls Jail Oppressive. Prosecutors Say She Has It Easy.
item.media:description: Prosecutors announced charges against Ghislaine Maxwell in July. This week, they disputed claims that her life in jail was oppressive.
item.description: Ms. Maxwell, a longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein, has asked to be released on $28.5 million bond as she awaits trial on federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Amy Julia Harris

item.title: Zoom Executive Accused of Disrupting Calls at China’s Behest
item.media:description: The federal case against Zoom is a fresh black eye for a company that has seen demand for its services skyrocket during the pandemic.
item.description: U.S. prosecutors have charged a company executive based in China with conspiring to terminate online meetings about the Tiananmen Square massacre.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong

item.title: Former Governor of Jalisco, Mexico, Is Killed in Puerto Vallarta
item.media:description: Aristóteles Sandoval, the former governor of the Mexican state of Jalisco, was killed Friday in Puerto Vallarta.
item.description: Aristóteles Sandoval was shot in the back inside a restaurant restroom in one of the highest-profile political killings in Mexico in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez

item.title: Tesla, Profitable at Last, Bulls Its Way Into the S&P 500
item.media:description: Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, takes a high-risk, high-return approach to building a business.
item.description: The electric-car maker will be the biggest addition in the history of the benchmark index. Will that settle down its swings?
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips

item.title: How May We Serve You? For Restaurant Chains, It Depends on the Location
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: With 43 locations scattered across the United States, Fogo De Chão has been dealing with a patchwork of pandemic regulations. At this location, in Rosemont Ill., only two panels of an outdoor structure must be kept open.
item.description: Large dine-in chains are finding it difficult to enact uniform approaches to the pandemic when dealing with different regulations across the country about how they can operate.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell and Gillian Friedman

item.title: Justices Put Off Ruling on Trump Plan for Unauthorized Immigrants and Census
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court’s ruling handed the Trump administration an interim victory, allowing it to pursue efforts that could shift the allotment of congressional seats and federal money to states that are older, whiter and typically more Republican.
item.description: The Supreme Court said a challenge to efforts to exclude unauthorized immigrants from the tabulations used to allocate House seats was premature.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak

item.title: Freed Nigeria Schoolboys Meet President Muhammadu Buhari
item.media:description: After being freed from their captors, the schoolboys were taken to the governor’s house to meet with the news media in Katsina, Nigeria, on Friday.
item.description: Capitalizing on a rare victory, the Nigerian government publicly displayed the more than 300 boys who had been released, and insisted it had not paid ransom.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Alfa

item.title: Buried Under Snow in a Car for 10 Hours. Who Would Come to the Rescue?
item.media:description: In the foreground, Sergeant Cawley’s vehicle; in the snowbank, Mr. Kresen’s.
item.description: The storm that blanketed a wide swath of upstate New York made one motorist’s car disappear until an ingenious state trooper found it.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.media:description: Rachel Griffiths, left, and Deborah Mailman in a scene from “Total Control.”
item.description: Looking for a prickly (and fictional) political drama or your next comedy binge? This weekend’s selections have you covered.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons

item.title: What to Cook This Weekend
item.media:credit: Andrew Purcell for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne
item.description: Revel in NYT Cooking’s end-of-year lists, with recipes for the days ahead.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sifton

item.title: Teaching My Kids to Drive While Black
item.description: I’ve raised them to be confident and to advocate for themselves. Now here I was saying, don’t do it with the police.
item.dc:creator: Suzanne McFayden

item.title: Escape From the City: 9 Winter Outings That Fight Cabin Fever
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Darren S. Higgins for The New York Times; Bill Bake; Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times; Kelli Klymenko
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, wild horses on Assateague Island (near Washington); sledding on the Blue Ridge Parkway (near Raleigh, N.C.); hiking in World’s End reservation (near Boston); and a winter landscape in Sedona, Ariz. (near Phoenix).
item.description: Snow biking near Seattle, winter bird-watching near New York and seven other cold-weather activities near large U.S. cities.

item.title: Watch Chadwick Boseman in a Scene From ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom’
item.description: The director George C. Wolfe discusses a tense sequence featuring the actor and Viola Davis.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: A 1958 ’Vette Translated Into Modern Chinese
item.media:description: It’s not a classic Corvette, it’s SongSan’s SS Dolphin. And it’s a gas-electric hybrid.
item.description: SongSan’s SS Dolphin is the latest in a long line of Chinese attempts at cloning more prominent vehicles.
item.category: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp
item.dc:creator: Jerry Garrett

item.title: What Qualifies as Success at Borussia Dortmund?
item.media:description: Three of Dortmund’s crown jewels: Giovanni Reyna, Erling Haaland and Jadon Sancho.
item.description: Borussia Dortmund’s business is winning matches and grooming some of the world’s best young talent. To do both, sometimes you have to put up with a few growing pains.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Swapping Songs With Chess Grandmaster Garry Kasparov
item.media:credit: Ted Thai/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Garry Kasparov, shown here in 1997, picked Beethoven’s Symphony No. 3 (“Eroica”) to share; our critic chose Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations.
item.description: Music brought a critic and a guest together, in a conversation about Bach, Beethoven, chess and politics.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim

item.title: What’s It Like to Cruise in the Covid Era? To Find Out, I Went Aboard
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.media:description: Capt. Robert Bodin with his deck officers aboard the World Dream.
item.description: A “cruise to nowhere” offered one correspondent a chance to understand an interesting trend, and to interview people in person.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

item.title: Covid Patient Study Shows Some Benefit From an Arthritis Drug
item.media:description: Gabriel Cervera Rodriguez, left, and Elizabeth Gamboa, middle, inserted a tube into a patient's chest at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston.
item.description: Baricitinib had previously attracted some scrutiny from experts, who were unsure when it would most help their patients.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: How Selfish Are Plants? Let’s Do Some Root Analysis
item.description: A new model further untangles the complex strategy games playing out under our feet.

item.title: Outer Space Just Got a Little Brighter
item.description: The universe is not as black as astronomers once thought.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Saving Corpse Flowers From Being Inbred to Extinction
item.media:description: Amorphophallus titanum on view at the New York Botanical Garden in 2018.
item.description: To preserve corpse flowers and other rare plants, botanic gardens are borrowing studbooks, an approach used by zoos and horse breeders.
item.category: Institute of Museum and Library Services
item.dc:creator: Samantha Drake

item.title: 8 Catholic Sisters Die of Covid-19 Within a Week at a Wisconsin Home
item.description: They were educators, music teachers and liturgists, living out their remaining years in a retirement residence after lifetimes of service.

Our Lady of the Angels Convent (Greenfield, Wis)

item.title: $700,000 Homes in New York, Rhode Island and Indiana
item.description: A soaring kit house in Catskill, a two-bedroom condominium in an 1852 mansion in Newport and a limestone house in Bloomington.

item.description: Use 7 letters to make as many words as you can.

item.title: U.S. State Department Closing Two Consulates In Russia
item.description: The announcement follows the revelation of a massive cyberattack against numerous government agencies as well as a number of private companies. Russian intelligence is widely believed responsible.
item.content:encoded:
The announcement follows the revelation of a massive cyberattack against numerous government agencies as well as a number of private companies. Russian intelligence is widely believed responsible.

(Image credit: Pavel Golovkin/AP)
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Romo

item.title: Maryland, Virginia To Send Extra COVID-19 Vaccine To D.C., Tripling Its Allotment
item.description: D.C.'s mayor urged the federal government to send more medicine to no avail. Now the states are sharing their supply to vaccinate health care workers who work in the capital but live elsewhere.
item.content:encoded:
D.C.'s mayor urged the federal government to send more medicine to no avail. Now the states are sharing their supply to vaccinate health care workers who work in the capital but live elsewhere.

(Image credit: Shawn Thew-Pool/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Romo

item.title: Stanford Apologizes After Vaccine Allocation Leaves Out Nearly All Medical Residents
item.description: Residents waged a protest on Friday, demanding to know why senior faculty were getting the vaccine before front-line workers who see COVID-19 patients. Stanford has agreed the plan was flawed.
item.content:encoded:
Residents waged a protest on Friday, demanding to know why senior faculty were getting the vaccine before front-line workers who see COVID-19 patients. Stanford has agreed the plan was flawed.

(Image credit: Ben Solomon)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: Moderna's COVID-19 Vaccine Becomes 2nd To Earn FDA Authorization
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration greenlights the biotech firm's vaccine for emergency use in the U.S. The move bolsters a vast inoculation effort that's already underway.
item.content:encoded:
The Food and Drug Administration greenlights the biotech firm's vaccine for emergency use in the U.S. The move bolsters a vast inoculation effort that's already underway.

(Image credit: Elise Amendola/AP)
item.dc:creator: Colin Dwyer

item.title: Newly Released COVID-19 Data Show Most U.S. Cities Are 'Sustained Hotspots'
item.description: A comprehensive dataset gives the American public the same view of the status of the pandemic that federal officials have but previously held back. The outlook is bleak.
item.content:encoded:
A comprehensive dataset gives the American public the same view of the status of the pandemic that federal officials have but previously held back. The outlook is bleak.

(Image credit: Department of Health and Human Services)
item.dc:creator: Liz Essley Whyte

item.title: 'Our Houses Are Not Safe': Residents Fear Taliban In Afghanistan's Capital
item.description: The Taliban have waged attacks across the country, prompting a call to reduce the violence from Gen. Mark Milley. In Kabul, the public worries about the Taliban's return.
item.content:encoded:
The Taliban have waged attacks across the country, prompting a call to reduce the violence from Gen. Mark Milley. In Kabul, the public worries about the Taliban's return.

item.dc:creator: Diaa Hadid

item.title: COVID-19 Relief Deal Stalled As Congress Passes 2-Day Stopgap Bill To Avoid Shutdown
item.description: As congressional leaders negotiate, other lawmakers are demanding more details. Plus, Democrats are objecting to a push by some Senate Republicans to limit emergency lending rules.
item.content:encoded:
As congressional leaders negotiate, other lawmakers are demanding more details. Plus, Democrats are objecting to a push by some Senate Republicans to limit emergency lending rules.

(Image credit: Susan Walsh/AP)
item.dc:creator: Deirdre Walsh

item.title: Massive Snowstorm Hits Japan, Trapping More Than 1,000 Cars On A Highway
item.description: "As time went by, the cars got buried," said a driver. "I was really scared." Japan's Self-Defense Forces distributed food, blankets and fuel to the stranded and worked with shovels to free vehicles.
item.content:encoded:
"As time went by, the cars got buried," said a driver. "I was really scared." Japan's Self-Defense Forces distributed food, blankets and fuel to the stranded and worked with shovels to free vehicles.

(Image credit: STR/Jiji Press/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: Pfizer Says Millions Of Vaccine Doses Are Ready, But States Say Shipments Were Cut
item.description: Pfizer is pushing back on the Trump administration's suggestion that the company is having trouble producing enough COVID-19 vaccine.
item.content:encoded:
Pfizer is pushing back on the Trump administration's suggestion that the company is having trouble producing enough COVID-19 vaccine.

(Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: 'A Huge Relief': 344 Schoolboys Released After Abduction In Nigeria
item.description: Last week's attack, claimed by Boko Haram, recalled the Islamist group's abduction of 276 girls in 2014. Unlike that attack, though, this fraught chapter ended relatively quickly, and with happy news.
item.content:encoded:
Last week's attack, claimed by Boko Haram, recalled the Islamist group's abduction of 276 girls in 2014. Unlike that attack, though, this fraught chapter ended relatively quickly, and with happy news.

(Image credit: Kola Sulaimon/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Colin Dwyer

item.title: Chart: COVID-19 Is Now Leading Killer In 5 Latin American Nations
item.description: Why are numbers so high in the region? Public health officials point to a number of underlying problems that let the coronavirus run amok.

Why are numbers so high in the region? Public health officials point to a number of underlying problems that let the coronavirus run amok.

item.title: Supreme Court Punts Census Case, Giving Trump An Iffy Chance To Alter Numbers
item.description: The opinion said the case was "riddled with contingencies and speculation" that impede judicial review. The president has sought to use a census count that does not include undocumented immigrants.
item.content:encoded:
The opinion said the case was "riddled with contingencies and speculation" that impede judicial review. The president has sought to use a census count that does not include undocumented immigrants.

(Image credit: Aurora Samperio/NurPhoto via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Dear Present Procrastinators: Ship That Holiday Gift, Now
item.description: If you haven't ordered gifts online yet, it may be too late to get them delivered by Christmas. More consumers are shopping online this year, and extra holiday demand is exceeding delivery capacity.
item.content:encoded:
If you haven't ordered gifts online yet, it may be too late to get them delivered by Christmas. More consumers are shopping online this year, and extra holiday demand is exceeding delivery capacity.

(Image credit: Ted S. Warren/AP)
item.dc:creator: David Schaper

item.title: Coronavirus World Map: Tracking The Spread Of The Outbreak
item.description: A map of confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths around the world. The respiratory disease has spread rapidly across six continents and has killed at least 1 million globally.
item.content:encoded:
A map of confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths around the world. The respiratory disease has spread rapidly across six continents and has killed at least 1 million globally.

(Image credit: NPR)

item.description: View NPR's maps and graphics to see where COVID-19 is hitting hardest in the U.S., which state outbreaks are growing and which are leveling off.

item.title: Covid: US approves Moderna as second vaccine
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration gives the green light for releasing millions of doses.

item.title: US cyber-attack: US energy department confirms it was hit by Sunburst hack
item.description: The agency is responsible for managing nuclear weapons, but said their security was not affected.

item.title: Covid: US Vice-President Mike Pence receives vaccine live on TV
item.description: "I didn't feel a thing," says Mr Pence after he receives his first dose of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine.

item.title: US fraternities busted for 'large-scale' drug ring
item.description: For two years, the group allegedly received 90kg (200lbs) of cannabis and 2kg of cocaine a week.

item.title: US judge says parents owe son over trashed porn collection
item.description: The 42-year-old sued his parents, saying they threw away an "irreplaceable" collection worth $25,000.

item.title: The Stand: Anger over actor cast in deaf role for Stephen King TV series
item.description: More than 70 people sign a letter saying Stephen King's new CBS show should have used a deaf actor.

item.title: Eminem uses song to say sorry to Rihanna for backing Chris Brown
item.description: The rapper uses a new song to apologise for "siding" with Brown, who assaulted the singer in 2009.

item.title: Deb Haaland: Historic Native American 'pick for Biden cabinet'
item.description: Deb Haaland would be the first Native American in a cabinet secretary role, overseeing public lands.

item.title: Covid: Moderna vaccine moves closer to US approval
item.description: Officials pledge to move quickly to approve the Moderna vaccine after it is endorsed by an expert panel.

item.title: Trump trade chief wants WTO leadership race reopened
item.description: Picking a new leader for the WTO will be a challenge for Joe Biden as the global economy struggles with coronavirus.

item.title: Tyler Perry, billionaire, opens up about mid-life crisis
item.description: The 51-year-old filmmaker says he's single and unsure about what the "next chapter" holds for him.

item.title: US snowstorm: Record-breaking blizzard slams East Coast
item.description: Over three feet fell in parts of northern New York, with hundreds of car crashes reported across the region.

item.title: Biden cabinet: Does this new team better reflect America?
item.description: The role of a president's inaugural cabinet goes beyond just policy - let's take a closer look.

item.title: US election 2020: Why Republicans are fighting in Georgia
item.description: Sparks fly as the traditionally Republican state that chose Joe Biden might also hand him the Senate.

item.title: US election 2020: What legal challenges remain for Trump?
item.description: The president says the result was "stolen" but his lawyers have so far had little success in court.

item.title: Alfred Bourgeois: Second death row inmate executed in two days
item.description: President Donald Trump has planned three more executions before he leaves office on 20 January.

item.title: In Trump’s final days, a rush of federal executions
item.description: The executions put Mr Trump on track to be the most prolific execution president in modern history.

item.title: Where does the Republican Party go after Trump?
item.description: What places like Ohio reveal about President Donald Trump's legacy on the Republican Party.

item.title: 'Brother against brother' in Trump country
item.description: What's it like to be a Biden voter in a Trump heartland where many believe the election was rigged?

item.title: Can Georgia's teenagers change Biden’s presidency?
item.description: Newly eligible voters could have a big impact on who controls the Senate and define the nature of Joe Biden's presidency.

item.title: Trump presidency's final days: 'In his mind, he will not have lost'
item.description: An eerie quiet has descended on the White House as attempts to challenge the election result founder.

item.title: What Biden's new foreign policy team tells us
item.description: US foreign policy experts weigh in on what the new slate of top diplomats means for global affairs.

item.title: Biden announces all-female senior press team
item.description: Joe Biden has pledged to shape one of the most diverse US presidential cabinets ever.

item.title: US evictions crisis: 'My pride has gone. We're pretty much homeless now'
item.description: Millions face being homeless as an eviction ban ends - and a lifeline from Congress remains uncertain.

item.title: How Phoebe Bridgers made one of 2020's best albums
item.description: The making of Punisher, from break-ups and primal screams to learning how to drive a tractor.

item.title: SolarWinds: Why the Sunburst hack is so serious
item.description: The hack of thousands of high-profile organisations, including the US government, could have major consequences.

item.title: USA v Iran: The historic 2000 friendly match planned to bring countries together
item.description: Two years after their historic World Cup match, USA and Iran met again in 2000. It was supposed to build bridges - but not everything went to plan.

item.title: Canada 'Sixties Scoop': Indigenous survivors map out their stories
item.description: Canada's "Sixties Scoop" saw thousands of indigenous children forcibly removed from their families.

item.title: Interior Chinatown: The novel taking on Hollywood’s Asian tropes
item.description: This year's winner of the US National Book Award for fiction explores what it means to be Asian in America.

item.title: Plexiglass, sanitiser and masks: US mall Santas prepare for Christmas
item.description: Malls that have hosted visits with Santa for over 100 years are being forced to change their approach.

item.title: Revenge of the secretaries: The protest movement that inspired the film 9 to 5
item.description: The 1980 hit comedy 9 to 5 was inspired by a real protest movement, which is profiled in a new documentary.

item.title: Covid vaccine: When will Americans be vaccinated?
item.description: The first doses of the Pfizer vaccine were to healthcare workers in the US on Monday.

item.title: Covid-19: The mask-wearing US city that bucked the trend
item.description: Compulsory mask-wearing has been highly controversial in the US.

item.title: Covid travel nurse's six months on the road across the US
item.description: Nurse Laura Liffiton has travelled across the US for six months, helping in the fight against Covid.

item.title: Melania’s tennis pavilion and other White House makeovers
item.description: As Melania Trump revamps the Tennis Pavilion, we look at how past presidencies have changed the White House.

item.title: School photo is viral internet meme, Adrian Smith finds
item.description: Adrian Smith discovered a photo of him taken when he was eight years old had a life of its own.

item.title: Florida puppy that escaped alligator's jaws becomes sheriff 'deputy dog'
item.description: Gunner, a five-month-old Cavalier King Charles Spaniel, is honoured by his local sheriff in Florida.

item.title: US election: Mitch McConnell congratulates Biden, White House talks 'ongoing litigation'
item.description: Mitch McConnell congratulates Joe Biden, while Trump's press secretary refers to "ongoing litigation".

item.title: Joe Biden: US democracy proved to be 'resilient and strong'
item.description: US President-elect Joe Biden says the country's system was "pushed, tested and threatened".

item.title: Coronavirus: The day US began Covid vaccinations
item.description: A massive vaccination effort has kicked off with healthcare workers first to get a vaccine.

item.title: Cher on Kaavan the 'lonely' elephant's rescue, Joe Biden and Mamma Mia 3
item.description: The singer helped to relocate Kaavan from a Pakistani zoo to a wildlife sanctuary in Cambodia.

item.title: What's it like moving back home (as an adult)?
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has led millions of young Americans to move back in with their parents.

item.title: Coronavirus: US doctor who has worked 258 days straight goes viral
item.description: Dr Joseph Varon believes he is fighting two wars. A war against coronavirus and a war against stupidity.

item.title: Plane makes emergency landing on US highway
item.description: A light aircraft is forced to make an emergency landing on an interstate in Minnesota, but no injuries are reported.

item.title: Puerto Rico: The moment the Arecibo Observatory telescope collapsed
item.description: Video shows one of the world's largest telescopes at Puerto Rico's Arecibo Observatory crashing down.

item.title: Trump 'stoking vast conspiracy' says Georgia election official
item.description: Gabriel Sterling, who's called out threats against workers, says the president's words "have consequences".

item.title: Why Donald Trump keeps outperforming the polls
item.description: He lost the election, but did better than most experts were predicting. How does this keep happening?

item.title: Animal crossing for Utah wildlife is 'working'
item.description: The overpass aims to help animals cross between two mountains while avoiding highway traffic.

item.title: Joe Biden: President-elect seen in protective boot on fractured foot
item.description: Joe Biden is seen wearing a protective boot on his right foot, which he fractured playing with his dog.

item.title: Actor Michael J Fox on his 'acceptance' of Parkinson's disease
item.description: The Back to the Future star on his battle with the disease and how he initially tried to hide his diagnosis.

item.title: 'Thanksgiving grandma' has bittersweet reunion with guest she invited by mistake
item.description: Wanda still invites Jamal to dinner four years after a mistaken text - but this year there was an empty seat.

item.title: New Christmas campaign for Canadians held in China
item.description: The campaign is based on efforts around a similar case involving a British journalist fifty years ago.

item.title: New Brunswick outbreak: How a smalltown doctor became a Covid pariah
item.description: After being labelled "patient zero", a small-town physician in Canada was shunned.

item.title: Covid: US approves Moderna as second vaccine
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration gives the green light for releasing millions of doses.

item.title: US cyber-attack: US energy department confirms it was hit by Sunburst hack
item.description: The agency is responsible for managing nuclear weapons, but said their security was not affected.

item.title: Covid: US Vice-President Mike Pence receives vaccine live on TV
item.description: "I didn't feel a thing," says Mr Pence after he receives his first dose of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine.

item.title: US fraternities busted for 'large-scale' drug ring
item.description: For two years, the group allegedly received 90kg (200lbs) of cannabis and 2kg of cocaine a week.

item.title: US judge says parents owe son over trashed porn collection
item.description: The 42-year-old sued his parents, saying they threw away an "irreplaceable" collection worth $25,000.

item.title: The Stand: Anger over actor cast in deaf role for Stephen King TV series
item.description: More than 70 people sign a letter saying Stephen King's new CBS show should have used a deaf actor.

item.description: The rapper uses a new song to apologise for "siding" with Brown, who assaulted the singer in 2009.

item.description: Deb Haaland would be the first Native American in a cabinet secretary role, overseeing public lands.

item.title: Covid: Moderna vaccine moves closer to US approval
item.description: Officials pledge to move quickly to approve the Moderna vaccine after it is endorsed by an expert panel.

item.description: Picking a new leader for the WTO will be a challenge for Joe Biden as the global economy struggles with coronavirus.

item.description: The 51-year-old filmmaker says he's single and unsure about what the "next chapter" holds for him.
